data.text: Is There a Difference Between GP2 and GP3 Ergon Grips?
Anybody has some experience with the ergon grip ? GP2 or GP3 and why
I have been using these for a year. They are holding up really well. I wish I had a larger size. But i have big hands.
data.author: Steve Thompson

data.text: which one did you take ?
data.author: Sylvain Poncet

data.text: I have the gp2
data.author: Steve Thompson

data.text: Thanks
data.author: Sylvain Poncet

data.text: GP3. Theyâ€™re great.
data.author: Chris Sutton

data.text: I have the GP2. I bought them because I wanted another hand position but I didnâ€™t want the bigger horns as I think they look a bit ridiculous. Matter of preference though.
data.author: Andrew Heindl

data.text: I have these and I am very proud of them. Good buy to buy. The longer I get the better.
data.author: Cudowne Dziecko

data.text: Thank you
data.author: Sylvain Poncet

data.text: Gp3 the plastic horn has some padding
data.author: Mono Doigt

data.text: I have the GP2â€™s, though only put them on my bike a few weeks ago. So far, I love them. Good hand support & I really like being able to change hand positions.
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: Iâ€™ve got a set of the 3â€™s that are basically new if interested
data.author: Matthew Corey

data.text: send me a message
data.author: Sylvain Poncet

data.text: Iâ€™ve used the GP3s for a couple years now. Iâ€™m happy with them. Holding up just fine. Iâ€™ve no desire to try something else. Probably would buy again when/if theses wear out.
data.author: Brian Gangelhoff

data.text: Iâ€™ve moved to the biocork version - which also means I have stopped using gloves. 3 is more useful for a proper change of hand position
data.author: Simon Usher

data.text: whatâ€™s the advantage of cork ?
data.author: Sylvain Poncet

data.text: the plastic ones go slippery and eventually sticky / start to degrade with sweat. The cork absorbs it
data.author: Simon Usher

data.text:
I have them, I'm not actually a huge fan. I find on longer rides, hand pain is worse than being able to slip my little finger over a normal bar end I've switched to this: https://ridefarr.com/product/farr-carbon-aero-bolt-on-v3/
Farr Carbon Aero Bolt-On V3 | Ridefarr
ridefarr.com
data.author: Mark Stacey

data.text: you don't have any discomfort along the fore arms?
data.author: Chris Gomez

data.text: with the ridefarr? No, not at all. It's my hands that get very sore during long rides, which the Farr bar helps with, and the ergon didn't
data.author: Mark Stacey

data.text: Mark Stacey, I found the same, they limit your hand position round the bar so you cant vary as much as you need. Scrapped these for foam grips and bar ends. Then moved to a Jones style bar.
data.author: Matt Watson

data.text: G3 for more to hold. Great on long rides and especially tours where your hands get beat up. I love them. The horizontal grip smooths buzz away, with good wrist position and the bar ends (wings, horns etc) are great for climbing and swapping position when hands are sore.
data.author: Patrick Thomas Hussey

data.text: Yes ! Went away from them for a season and regretted it. Back on the bars now though.
data.author: Chris Danaceau

data.text: Havenâ€™t used the GP2/3 but have had 2-4 sets of the GP for the last 12 years. They follow me to each bike. Iâ€™ve ridden bikes without Ergon grips here and there over the years but always run them on my bikes. Actually looking to get the gp3 this weekend for my bikepacking rig.
data.author: James Falke

data.text: I'm using GP2 in my Canyon Roadlite bike (OEM mounted). The longer I go the more I put my hands on them. Very comfortable ! I do recommend them however if I would buy them now I would take GP3 for better and longer hold. Take GP3 Mate!
data.author: Piotr Pieczyski

data.text: I have GP2's Fantastic
data.author: Scott Crombie

data.text: can I please get the link to that bottle holder? That thing is awesome. Lol.
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: try ebay for 'Bike Bottle Cage Adaptor' There's several different kinds
data.author: Scott Crombie

data.text: the bar that they're attached to is just a cheap handlebar extension off ebay
data.author: Scott Crombie

data.text: Awesome. Thanks!
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: GP5! ðŸ˜€
data.author: Martin Jahr

data.text: Def go with 3 or 4.
data.author: Ezekiel Tallant

data.text: I have the 2â€™s. Thinking of trying the 1â€™s and the SQ Labs inner bar ends. The outer bar end kinda gets in my way.
data.author: Jack Driver

data.text: Holding that bar with 4 fingers felt most natural to me. Wouldnt you want to grab with the pinky too?
data.author: Ezekiel Tallant

data.text: so youâ€™re saying that youâ€™re using the GP4 or 5 ?
data.author: Sylvain Poncet

data.text: gp4.
data.author: Ezekiel Tallant

data.text: I use them, their pitfall is they'll grab onto a bush. Be ready to correct when that happens. A lot of trails won't have this as an issue though.
data.author: Sean Mankiw

data.text: Iâ€™m already running bar ends but not as comfy
data.author: Sylvain Poncet

data.text: GP5! ðŸ˜€ Been riding mine on tight trails for 2 years. They litterally cant snag trees. Thats 50%of why I Keep them; forest-proof bar ends.
data.author: Martin Jahr

data.text: I have used them on wide 800mm bars and that proved too wide for them to be comfortable. Have fitted bar ends inside my brake levers now which works really well
data.author: Rob Crates

data.text: I have Ergon grips on all my mountain bikes. For me, the grip offers a more restful and Ergon"omic" hand position, especially for marathon and beyond (4 to 10 to ... hour) length rides. However, I do not get the bar ends. The consequences of hooking a bar end on a tree or branch has catastrophic potential. For non-technical riding (touring, bikepacking) bar ends might be fine.
data.author: Carl Gable

data.text: Got gp3 and love em. On a touring bike.
data.author: Ross Anderson

data.text: I have Ergon grips on 3 of my bikes, once they are adjusted properly, so that the back of the palm can rest on them, they are very comfortable. I have GP5, GC1 and GS1.
data.author: Martin Storli

data.text: Ride them on my MTB without the bar ends. Like the flat area for my palms.
data.author: Dave Campbell

data.text: Campbell"> I like my drop handelbars, like it because my hands feel natural,.....just shut the f up Dave with comments like this, you're no help at all
data.author: Steve Sys

data.text: you donâ€™t put those grips on drop bars asshole. So why donâ€™t you go F yourself. I donâ€™t really give a shit what kinda bars you ride. That was the question OP asked. Peace out!
data.author: Dave Campbell
Sylvain Poncet

data.text: I am a huge fan of ergons. Theyre like the birkenstock of handlebar grips. Feels like a massage when holding them!
data.author: Mitchell Asido

data.text: I got the GP3's. Being able to change hand positions really helps avoid repetitive motion injury and sometimes climbing just feels better with a different hand position.
data.author: Jim Miner

data.text: The GP2â€™s ends are too small to be useful for anything but stopping your hands from sliding off the end of the grips. You can grab them with your little finger and the next but itâ€™s not comfortable.
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: Iâ€™m using GA3 and like them a lot.
data.author: Jarrod Patrone
Jarrod Patrone

data.text: Iâ€™ve used them. Am a fan.
data.author: Joe Jeffery

data.text: Loved the GP2 until I got jones bars, they donâ€™t work with the swoop back bars, unfortunately. Used then for a long time before that, though. Really comfortable. I found the shorter knobs on the GP2 more comfortable that the long ones on the GP3.
data.author: Troy Ascher

data.text: Have them on my MTB. Very comfy
data.author: Justin Abbott

data.text: They are built nicely but I don't like bar ends on large handlebars. I would prefer inner bar extensions.
data.author: Gerry Andrews

data.text: I had GP3 and ended up cutting the bar ends off - seriously. Obnoxious things.
data.author: Glen Carter

data.text: i thought the bar end was modular and could be replaced by an end cap ?
data.author: Sylvain Poncet

data.text: Don't know. I do know that a hacksaw and a file fixed 'em!
data.author: Glen Carter
Sylvain Poncet

data.text: Had the Ergon gp3 on my Surly Karate Monkey for two years. So comfy and durable ðŸ˜„ They are the setup for every bikepacking adventure!
data.author: Brett Neff
